awd_titl_txt: EAGER/Collaborative Research: Enable Elastic Capacity for Transportation Infrastructure through a Transmodal Modular Autonomous Vehicle System
awd_abstract_narration:
While roadway infrastructure provides limited capacity, vehicles operating on roads dominated by passenger cars may easily exceed road capacity over peak hours, causing traffic congestion, excessive energy consumption and increased safety risks. In observing that a passenger car takes much space on a roadway due to the relatively long gap following a preceding vehicle, this EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project explores emerging modular autonomous vehicle (MAV) technology that can dynamically adjust gaps between vehicles. With the MAV technology, vehicles composed of multiple modular pods can be dynamically docked and separated during operations. For example, during peak hours, modular pods will be docked into longer MAVs, resulting in zero gaps between the modular pods docked together, which obviously improves highway throughput and reduces congestion. Whereas during off-peak hours, a long MAV may separate into shorter MAVs to ensure flexible system accessibility and reduce vehicle operation costs. This way, the MAV service equivalently creates “elastic” capacity for fixed transportation infrastructure to adapt spatiotemporally-varying travel demand. This project is for a new transmodal MAV system paradigm to realize such elastic capacity of a road transportation system. 

To realize this vision, we will adapt multidisciplinary theoretical methods (e.g., time-geography, queuing theory, traffic flow theory, and homogeneous analysis) to understand and formulate operations of an MAV system. Then we will build mathematical models for the optimal design and operations of an MAV system at various scales by synchronizing demands and modular pods over time and space. The major challenge is to deal with continuous time and space as opposed to traditional fleet management problems with discrete time-space states. This challenge will be overcome by integrating microscopic trajectory control into macroscopic fleet management. If successful, this project will provide transmodal concepts to improve transportation and other related systems that are currently segregated into different modes. It will help boost the MAV service from a startup stage to a sustainable industry. The results will help transportation stakeholders understand feasibility and benefits of the MAV service and devise measures to incorporate it in their future planning, which may result in profound positive impacts on surface transportation including transit and freight operations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Modular autonomous vehicle (MAV) technology offers a transformative paradigm to address the growing mismatch between static roadway capacity and dynamic travel demand. In conventional vehicle systems, fixed vehicle sizes and constant inter-vehicle gaps limit capacity, particularly during peak periods. In contrast, MAV systems enable modular pods to dynamically dock into longer units during high-demand periods and split during off-peak hours for flexible access and reduced cost. This concept effectively realizes elastic capacity for fixed infrastructure, adapting system form to shifting spatial and temporal demand. This EAGER project explores the theoretical foundations, modeling frameworks, and real-world applications needed to enable such a transmodal MAV system.

This project integrated traffic flow theory, time geography, queuing models, and control theory with multi-scale optimization and artificial intelligence to realize the MAV vision. A key modeling challenge involved bridging the traditionally separate realms of microscopic vehicle dynamics and macroscopic fleet operations. To address this, the project developed a unified framework combining trajectory-level control and system-level optimization.

At the trajectory level, the team formulated and solved new classes of docking and platooning trajectory planning problems. These problems were cast as multi-stage optimization models, where docking—viewed as an extreme case of AV platooning with zero inter-vehicle gap—was solved using a hybrid of Pontryagin’s principle and quadratic programming. A novel feasible-cone method was introduced to guarantee trajectory feasibility, while heuristic and exact approaches provided both theoretical insights and practical algorithms suitable for real-time applications.

At the operational level, the project proposed a Modular Vehicle Routing Problem (MVRP) to enable MAVs to dynamically adjust delivery routes and configurations en route. The MVRP generalizes the classical vehicle routing problem by incorporating pod-docking mechanisms and platooning cost models. Exact and heuristic (e.g., Tabu Search) methods were developed to solve large-scale instances efficiently. Applications in airport baggage logistics showed that MAV-based systems can significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions while maintaining on-time performance.

Safety control was another critical thrust of this project. A distributed safety-assurance controller integrating adaptive Model Predictive Control and Control Barrier Functions was developed to ensure collision-free docking and separation under uncertainty. The research also explored intelligent MAV control using hybrid learning frameworks. A physics-enhanced residual learning (PERL) controller was proposed for connected vehicle platooning, combining interpretable physics-based models with online neural network updates. Compared to baseline models, PERL substantially improved trajectory tracking and robustness to disturbances, validated through both simulations and physical robot-car tests. Field tests using reduced-scale MAVs demonstrated reliable real-time performance.

This project produced a foundational body of knowledge to support the deployment of modular vehicle systems in diverse transportation contexts—from aviation to urban logistics. Results have been disseminated through multiple peer-reviewed publications, including in Transportation Research Part E and Communications in Transportation Research, with further papers under revision. In addition, the project supported interdisciplinary training for graduate and undergraduate students in optimization, control, and intelligent systems, while developing open-source datasets and algorithms to accelerate future research.

By demonstrating that MAV systems can improve throughput, safety, and environmental sustainability while enabling adaptive, multi-modal integration, this project lays the groundwork for a new generation of resilient and elastic transportation systems.
